oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Harlan Howard Interviewed by Bob Allen in 1988 Side One
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of Bob Allen interviewing Harlan Howard. The recording takes place on 06-17-1988.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Harlan Howard
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side One - (0:12) -- Bob Allen begins interview by asking Harlan Howard if he writes music at home. (0:34) -- Harlan Howard describes writing songs in the morning at Music Row. (1:35) -- Harlan Howard describes the process of receiving feedback on your own songwriting. (3:06) -- Harlan Howard describes his relationship with other songwriters in Nashville, TN. Harlan describes his respect for other songwriter's material and the difficulty of finding an original idea for a song. (5:19) -- Bob Allen asks Harlan Howard about a resurgence of his songwriting. Harlan describes going through a divorce and how that can mentally block songwriting. (7:02) -- Harlan Howard describes his competitive nature when songwriting. (8:44) -- Harlan Howard describes the need for having fun while trying for commercial songs. (9:17) -- Bob Allen asks Harlan Howard when he first began writing. Harlan Howard cites Ernest Tubb and Floyd Tillman as some of his influences. (11:43) -- Harlan Howard discusses being in the army and learning guitar from a fellow trooper from Oklahoma. Harlan left the army at the age of 21. (12:27) -- Harlan Howard describes moving to L.A. and pitching songs to publishers in Hollywood, CA. (13:25) -- Harlan Howard describes pitching a song to Johnny Bond and Tex Ritter. (14:05) -- Harlan Howard mentions writing songs with Buck Owens. (14:51) -- Harlan Howard describes being well acquainted with Bobby Bare. (15:35) -- Harlan Howard mentions why he moved out to the coast [California]. (16:07) -- Harlan Howard discusses the birth of Tin Pan Alley, Nashville. Mentions Hank Cochran, Roger Miller, Bill Anderson, Mel Tillis, Wayne Walker, Boudleaux Bryant. (17:18) -- Harlan Howard mentions his fondness for K.T. Oslin. (18:29) -- Harlan Howard describes pitching songs for Chet Atkins and Owen Bradley. (19:49) -- Harlan Howard describes his fondness for Owen Bradley and Chet Atkins. (20:31) -- Harlan Howard mentions his own publishing company "Wilderness Music." (21:59) -- Harlan Howard mentions that he wrote most of the music for "Wilderness Music." (23:35) -- Harlan Howard describes the challenge of pitching songs to artists. (26:19) -- Harlan Howard speaks about Nanci Griffith's method of songwriting. (29:50) -- Harlan Howard mentions that he loves to write songs for women. (31:08) -- Harlan Howard speaks about Waylon Jennings recording 74 of his songs. (32:00) -- Harlan Howard mentions that he is currently writing for Tree Publishing as a staff writer.
